item.title: All under one roof: insourcing LDI
item.description:
All under one roof: insourcing LDI

As the trend for larger pension funds to insource management of their assets increases, Pádraig Floyd asks whether an in-house approach to liability driven investment will be the next step.

item.title: UK retirement savings are still falling short - raconteur.net
item.description:
UK retirement savings are still falling short - raconteur.net

The greatest change to pensions since the old age pension was introduced a century ago was auto-enrolment. Since October 2012, more than 5.2 million UK workers have started saving for their retirement - an increase of almost 60 per cent.

item.title: The problems facing AVCs in a post-DB world
item.description:
The problems facing AVCs in a post-DB world

It is fair to say reviewing AVC schemes is not high on trustees' agendas. However, Pádraig Floyd looks at why this area needs more attention.

item.title: HR Viewpoints – Benefits fatigue and how to combat it
item.description:
HR Viewpoints – Benefits fatigue and how to combat it

One of the biggest risks for employers with generous or engaging benefits schemes is employees getting benefit fatigue - in other words, so used to the benefits they fail to value them any longer. Andrew Drake, head of reward & benefits at JLT Employee Benefits, likens this to the ceaseless development of the Apple iPhone.

item.title: HR Viewpoints – What is a benefits package worth?
item.description:
HR Viewpoints – What is a benefits package worth?

The best marketing resource any business can have is its workforce. A Reed survey found that 58% of employees grumble about their benefits package, but at the same time a benefits package was cited as the third-most important factor for jobseekers at 30% (behind brand image and reputation, which scored 37%, and salary at 33%).

item.title: HR Viewpoints – Three steps to heaven
item.description:
HR Viewpoints – Three steps to heaven

Employers spend a lot of money on providing benefits for their workers. In the UK, that can be as much as 20%-30% of total compensation, whereas in the US the average cost of employee benefits have topped 30% as a result of rising health insurance costs.
